metadata./Keywords: Dobhoff tube; Perforation; Roux-en-Y surgery; Iatrogenic injury; Endoscopic intervention
metadata./Title: Gastrojejunostomy junction perforation resulting from Dobhoff tube insertion in a patient with a history of Roux-en-Y surgery: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Gastrojejunostomy junction perforation is a rare yet critical complication associated with enteral tube 
placement, presenting unique challenges in patients with a history of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 63-year-old white female with a complex medical history, including heart failure, atrial 
fibrillation, stage 4 chronic kidney disease, and prior Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery in 2015, experienced 
a significant decline in her health. She was discharged to a skilled nursing facility after a fall but deteriorated rapidly 
in the 2 weeks before admission. She presented with symptoms of failure to thrive, abdominal/back pain, inability 
to eat or drink, constipation, and stool incontinence. Lab tests showed anemia, electrolyte imbalances, and acute 
kidney injury. Imaging confirmed Roux-en-Y gastric bypass anatomy and a small hiatal hernia. Despite treatment 
attempts, her condition worsened. Nutrition discussions led to a temporary Dobhoff tube placement, considering 
her Roux-en-Y gastric bypass history, with plans for a gastrostomy tube. However, Dobhoff tube placement 
posed challenges, and imaging later revealed perforation near the gastrojejunostomy junction. After consulting 
with the family, the decision was made to transition the patient to comfort care due to her overall condition. 
Yearly education of staff about Roux-en-Y gastric bypass anatomy and updated Dobhoff placement protocol 
was implemented with physician oversight. Further imaging protocol in a patient who had had a Roux-en-Y gastric 
bypass was updated to include fluoroscopic guidance when endoscopic placement was unavailable.
Conclusions This case highlights the intricacies of managing patients with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass history 
and underscores the need for meticulous planning and consideration of anatomical variations when performing 
procedures involving the gastrointestinal tract and the importance of involving multiple healthcare disciplines 
in complex decision-making and preventive measures to enhance patient safety in similar cases.
Keywords  Dobhoff tube, Perforation, Roux-en-Y surgery, Iatrogenic injury, Endoscopic intervention
Background
In the USA, the prevalence of severe obesity [body 
mass index (BMI) ≥ 40] over the age of 20 years was 
9.2% in 2018 [1]. The major treatment for severe 
obesity is bariatric surgery, with approximately 700,000 
procedures internationally in 2018 [2]. The two most 
common procedures are gastric sleeve (GS) and Rouxen-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), accounting for 55.4% and Open Access

Medical Case Reports
*Correspondence:
Monty Khela
msk13989@creighton.edu
1 School of Medicine at Creighton University, 7500 Mercy Rd, Omaha, NE

Page 2 of 6 Khela et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:482 
29.2% of procedures, respectively [2]. While the total 
GS procedures are greater than primary RYGB, there 
is subset of patients in GS who are converted to RYGB 
due to postoperative complications [3]. RYGB stands 
as a frequently performed bariatric surgical procedure 
profoundly reshaping the gastrointestinal anatomy. 
Notably, individuals who have undergone RYGB surgery 
face distinctive complications when subjected to 
subsequent medical interventions, such as the insertion 
of enteral feeding tubes. Dobhoff tubes, also recognized 
as nasoenteric or nasojejunal tubes, represent slender, 
pliable feeding conduits that traverse the nasal passage, 
traverse the esophagus, and eventually reach the jejunum 
within the small intestine. Their application in clinical 
contexts encompasses the provision of enteral nutrition, 
medication administration, or gastric decompression [4]. 
Although Dobhoff tubes offer clear merits, including ease 
of insertion and diminished aspiration risk compared 
with gastric tubes, they are not exempt from potential 
complications. Among these, issues such as tube 
displacement or dislodgement and intra-gastrointestinal 
kinking or coiling, as well as nasal irritation and sinusitis 
are prevalent [4, 5]. In rare instances, more serious 
complications may manifest, including tube-related 
pneumonia and gastrointestinal perforation, particularly 
in patients with a history of RYGB due to the altered 
anatomy, notably involving the gastrojejunostomy 
junction. A comprehensive understanding of these risks, 
coupled with a profound appreciation of the importance 
of meticulous tube placement, is paramount in 
furnishing secure and efficacious nutritional support for 
patients with a history of RYGB. This case report serves 
as an illustrative instance highlighting the potential 
challenges and complications inherent in Dobhoff tube 
placement for such individuals, underscoring the need 
for heightened vigilance and precision in clinical practice.
Case presentation
A 63-year-old white female patient with a complex 
medical history, including heart failure with preserved 
ejection fraction (HFpEF), atrial fibrillation, stage 
4 chronic kidney disease (CKD), hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, iron deficiency anemia, transient 
ischemic attack, and a history of RYGB in 2015, was 
admitted due to severe abdominal and back pain, as 
well as a general decline in her health. This decline had 
been occurring over the last 2  weeks, during which she 
experienced difficulty eating and drinking, had been 
wheelchair-bound, and had issues with constipation and 
bowel incontinence. This deterioration followed a fall 
she had suffered 3 months prior, leading to a prolonged 
hospitalization and subsequent discharge to a skilled 
nursing facility.Upon her initial presentation, the patient was in 
significant distress, with a blood pressure of 90/60  mm 
Hg that improved after receiving intravenous fluids. 
Physical examination revealed abdominal distention 
and pain, which worsened upon palpation. Apart from 
her known chronic iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 
7.3  g/dL) and elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)-tocreatinine (Cr) ratio (53/1.5) due to her stage 4 CKD, 
initial laboratory
sections.Results:
results were unremarkable, except for 
a prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI), characterized by a 
fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) < 0.1% and a urine 
sodium of 19 mEq/L. A computed tomography (CT) scan 
of the chest and abdomen revealed hepatomegaly and 
confirmed the presence of a previous RYGB procedure 
along with a small hiatal hernia. Small hiatal hernias are 
common in patients undergoing gastric bypass surgery 
(40%), but are infrequently repaired in patients with a 
history of RYGB due to expected weight loss and damage 
to the crus of the diaphragm [6].
The patient received an intravenous fluid bolus 
and was placed on maintenance fluids to manage her 
AKI, but her condition did not significantly improve 
throughout her hospital stay. The cause of abdominal 
pain remained inconclusive, and initial lab workup, 
which included liver enzymes, lipase, and amylase, were 
unremarkable. CT of the abdomen with and without 
contrast and ultrasound (U/S) did not point towards 
any cause. Thoracic and lumbar CT was done to further 
evaluate back pain; the results showed degenerative 
changes, along with postoperative changes of discectomy 
and spinal fusion. On reading further about previous 
hospitalizations, it was noted she had abdominal pain 
mentioned in the multiple hospitalizations, over the last 
1  year. It was concluded abdominal pain was chronic 
without any known specific etiology. Abdominal pain 
persisted on day 2 post-admission with poor oral intake 
and borderline hypotension with ultrasound findings of 
slight hepatosplenomegaly and unchanged renal cysts. 
On day 3, an acute drop in hemoglobin with the presence 
of melena was found, and the patient received 2 units of 
packed red blood cells. After the hemoglobin stabilized, 
a gastroenterologist (GI) was consulted for endoscopy 
and colonoscopy; however, the GI team deferred the 
procedure to the outpatient setting due to the patient’s 
stabilized Hg upon subsequent lab tests.
Given the patient’s ongoing nutrition concerns and 
after consultations on day 4 with her family and the GI 
team, it was decided that placing a Dobhoff tube would 
be the safest temporary solution over the weekend, 
with consideration of a gastrostomy tube (G-Tube) for 
a permanent nutritional solution to be addressed on 
Monday (day 6). This decision was influenced by her 
history of bariatric surgery, which posed an increased 
Page 3 of 6
 Khela et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:482 
 
risk of stomach perforation during G-Tube placement. 
Initially, the patient declined the Dobhoff tube, but with 
the assistance of her family, the tube was successfully 
placed on the fourth day of her hospitalization, and its 
correct placement was confirmed via an anteroposterior 
(AP) radiograph (Fig. 1A).
Unfortunately, the patient removed the Dobhoff  
tube overnight, and it had to be repositioned by a 
nurse the following morning on the fifth day, with 
placement deemed “sufficient” on AP x-ray (Fig.  1B). Despite receiving only 30  mL of tube feed, the patient 
complained of severe, constricting abdominal pain 
resembling a band-like sensation. A CT scan as soon as 
possible (STAT) of the abdomen was promptly ordered, 
revealing a perforation in the gastric pouch near the 
gastrojejunostomy, accompanied by pneumoperitoneum 
and a small amount of free fluid (Fig.  2). After 
confirmation, appropriate antibiotics/antifungal therapy 
was initiated for prophylaxis.
Initially, the family discussed proceeding with surgery, 
but after consulting with the general surgery team, they 
ultimately chose to pursue comfort care for the patient. 
A well-structured timeline documenting the patient’s 
journey throughout her hospitalization can be seen 
below in Table 1.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Nasogastric (NG) tube misplacement in a patient with 
history of RYGB presents a procedural challenge due 
to the surgical anatomy of the bypass and reduction in 
area for enteral feeding. The standard equation for NG 
tube insertion {[(NEX − 50)/2] + 50} averages 58  cm 
for standard anatomy with the consideration that 
8  cm must be within the stomach to avoid aspiration 
of fluids. However, the length of the stomach pouch 
in patients who have had Roux-en-y is 5  cm with highrisk anatomical areas including the gastrojejunal 
anastomosis [7]. An alternative to NG placement was 
direct percutaneous endoscopic jejunostomy (DPEJ), but 
this was avoided due to the patient’s surgical anatomy. 
Lowering the threshold for interventional radiology (IR)guided NG tube placement could procedurally reduce 
the risk of bowel perforation in patients with previous 
RYGB [8, 9].
The role of multidisciplinary communication is vital 
to reduce the risk of bowel perforation in patients with 
previous RYGB. The lack of communication of this

of Dobhoff placement on day 5
Fig. 2 CT scan showing Dobhoff perforating the gastric pouch 
near the gastrojejunostomy and small pneumoperitoneum 
with a little amount of free fluid

 Khela et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:482 
 
patient’s past history of RYGB between interdisciplinary 
team members introduced error into the management 
of patient safety. To address this issue, the protocol 
for conditions list within the electronic health record 
(EHR) was updated to include bariatric surgeries due 
to their risk of complications [10, 11]. Additionally, 
multidisciplinary education covering the risk of NG 
insertion in patients with history of RYGB was enacted 
to improve risk assessment. Through analysis of this 
event, it was also determined that education of travel 
nurses with onboarding education would be used to 
comprehensively resolve this error.
In the management of NG tubes in patients with 
RYGB anatomy, it is difficult to verify placement through 
radiological studies due to incomplete patient histories. 
As the population of patients who receive gastric bypass 
surgery increases and ages, it is important to effectively 
communicate remote patient history in the acute care 
setting. With effective communication, patients can be 
positioned appropriately to visualize their surgically 
altered anatomy and effective placement of NG tubes. 
The recommended x-ray view to visualize the NG 
placement in patients with a history of RYGB is the lateral 
oblique view [12]. With the use of this positioning in 
response to the altered RYGB anatomy with the improved 
communication and IR-guided NG tube placement, these 
situations can be prevented in the future.
The timeline of treatment in medically complex 
patients with RYGB requires the interdisciplinary team 
to have a continuum of effective communication. On 
day 4 after admission, the GI was consulted about the 
placement of NG considering the history of RYGB 
and planned for IR-guided G Tube placement on the 
following Monday. Despite early discussion of RYGB 
history, the breakdown of communication between shift 
change and travel nurses produced an environment 
where the risk of bowel perforation was increased. To 
correct for this error, staff education is recommended to 
cover the proper procedure and safety measures during 
placement of NG tubes. Further policy change should 
include supervised placement of NG tubes by the GI or 
attending physician.
The placement of temporary enteral feeding on a 
Saturday should include discussion of the increased 
risk of mistakes made over the weekend due to staff  
shortages and decreases in quality of care. Several 
studies have found a decline in care and increased 
length of stay when patients admitted to the hospital 
wait over the weekend to undergo surgery [13, 14]. 
In this case the interdisciplinary team must correct 
treatment plans to account for changing team dynamics 
over the weekend. For example, handoff notes must 
include a patient’s RYGB status and dictate protocol for complications such as NG tube removal. Addressing 
environments without RYBG experience, the NG tube 
protocol was updated to include a quick reference 
handout for nursing staff to avoid miscommunication 
about the contraindications for NG tube placement.
Imaging in patients with a distant history of Rouxen-Y should include fluoroscopic guidance to assess for 
anastomotic leaks and relative position of post-surgical 
anatomy. In this case the distant history of the Rouxen-Y was known, but the electronic medical record 
(EMR) did not contain previous images for radiological 
comparison. The lack of comparative studies for the 
patient’s surgical anatomy created relatively unknown 
landmarks for the radiologist. The recommendation 
for NG tube placement in patients with a history 
of RYGB is endoscopically to avoid perforation at 
the gastrojejunal junction [7 , 15]. When endoscopic 
placement is not available, the NG tube placement 
should be verified in the left posterior oblique position 
with fluoroscopy [12].
In
sections.Conclusion:
conclusion, this case underscores the intricate 
challenges and potential complications associated 
with Dobhoff tube placement in patients with a 
history of RYGB surgery and hiatal hernia. The altered 
gastrointestinal anatomy, particularly involving the 
gastrojejunostomy junction, poses unique risks for 
perforation and other severe complications. Despite 
its benefits, such as reduced aspiration risk, the use of 
Dobhoff tubes demands a meticulous approach, and 
healthcare providers must remain vigilant to minimize 
potential issues. In the rare presentation of not only 
RYGB but RYGB with comorbid hiatal hernia, it is 
crucial to emphasize the need for ongoing research 
aimed at refining and enhancing procedures for such 
patients to improve clinical decision-making. This 
case serves as a poignant reminder of the need for 
heightened awareness and precision in clinical practice 
when managing the nutritional needs of individuals 
with complex surgical histories.
Abbreviations
RYGB  Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
CKD  Chronic kidney disease
HFpEF  Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
BUN  Blood urea nitrogen
Cr  Creatinine
AKI  Acute kidney injury
FENa  Fractional excretion of sodium
CT  Computed tomography
GI  Gastroenterolgist
G-Tube  Gastrostomy tube
AP  Anterior posterior radiograph
NG  Nasogastric
NEX  Distance from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to xiphoid process
DPEJ  Direct percutaneous endoscopic jejunostomy
IR  Interventional radiology
EHR  Electronic health record
